h.en: The History of Fishing in Lewis

s.gd: ’S ann air eachdraidh iasgach an sgadain a tha Seumas MacThómais a’ toirt cunntais an so.
s.en: It is the history of herring fishing that James Thompson is giving an account of here.

s.gd: Tha sinn an dòchas gu lean e air an sgeul is gun toir e dhuinn uair eile eachdraidh air seòrsachan iasgaich eile.
s.en: We hope that the story will continue and that he will give us another time a history of other kinds of fishing.

s.gd: Anns an earrann eile de’n chunntas so gheibh sinn cuideachd sealladh air caitheamh-beatha nan iasgairean agus clann-nighean an sgadain.
s.en: In the other chapter of this account we will also get a look at the lifestyle of the fishermen and the herring girls.

h.gd: An t-seann “Mhùirneag”—am bàta iasgaich a b’ainmeile a bha’n Leódhas riamh.
h.en: The old “Darling”– the most famous fishing boat that was ever in Lewis.

s.gd: CHAN eil cunntas againn gu robh obair iasgaich a’ dol air adhart mu chladaichean Leódhais roimh thoiseach an t-siathamh linne deug, ach tha fios againn gu robh na Deasaich ag iasgach anns na lochan mu thimchioll an Eilein fad iomadh bliadhna mus tàinig deireadh an linne sin.
s.en: We have no account that fishing work was going on arond the shores of Lewis before the start of the sixteenth century, but we know that the people of South Uist were fishing in the lochs around the island for many a year before the end of that century had come.

s.gd: Tha e air aithris nach robh na Leódhasaich idir buidheach leis an obair-sa, agus gun do chuir iad campar gu minic air na coigrich.
s.en: It has been reported that the Lewismen were not at all satisfied with *their* work, and that they often annoyed the strangers.

s.gd: Thugadh oidhirp uair agus uair, le ughdarras an rìgh, air obair iasgaich a chur air chois anns na h-Eileanan a Siar ann am fìor thoiseach an t-seachdamh linne deug, agus rinneadh dà phort iasgaich, fear aca an Loch nam Madadh an Uidhist a Tuath, agus fear eile air Caolas na Hearradh.
s.en: An attempt was made time and again, with the authorisation of the king, to set up fishing work in the Western Isles at the very start of the seventeenth century, and to fishing ports were made, one of them in Lochmaddy in North Uist, and another one on the Straits of Harris.

s.gd: Bha an t-uachdaran a bha air Leódhas aig an ám ’na dhuine geur-sheallach, agus chuir e roimhe gum biodh a chuid aige-san de shaidhbhreas na mara.
s.en: The laird tha was on Lewis at the time was a sharp-sighted man, and he decided that he would have his share of the wealth of the sea.

s.gd: Thug e cuireadh do dh’ iasgairean as an Olaind an dachaidhean a dhèanamh an Steòrnabhagh agus thug e cothrom iasgaich dhaibh mar bu mhath leotha.
s.en: He invited fishermen from Holland to make their homes in Stornoway and he gave them the opportunity to fish as they would like.

s.gd: Shoirbhich leotha gu ro mhath, agus fad bhliadhnachan bha móran éisg a’ dol á Steòrnabhagh dh’ ionnsaigh Tìr-mór agus gu ruige an Olaind.
s.en: They succeeded very well, and for centuries a lot of fish were going from Stornoway towards the mainland and as far as Holland.

s.gd: Lean so gus na bhris cogadh a mach eadar an dùthaich sin agus Sasuinn anns a’ bhliadhna 1653 nuair a b’ fheudar do na h-Olaindich Leódhas fhàgail le òrdugh an riaghaltais.
s.en: This continued until war broke out between that country and England in the year 1653 when the Dutch had to leave Lewis by order of the government.

s.gd: Bha nis móran de shluagh Leòdhais air tlachd a ghabhail anns an iasgach air chor agus gun do lean iad a’ mhuir fad linntean an déidh sin.
s.en: There were now a lot of the Lewis people taking pleasure in fishing with the result that they followed the sea for centuries after that.

s.gd: Tha e r’a chreidsinn nach robh iasgairean anns a’ Ghaidhealtachd air fad a thug barr orra gus an latha an diugh.
s.en: It is to be believed that there aren’t fishermen in the whole of the HIghlands who exceeded them until the present day.

s.gd: Chaidh àireamh iasgairean Leódhais an lìonmhoireachd ré an ochdamh linne deug ionnus nach robh bàgh no geodha ceithir thimchioll nan cladaichean anns nach fhaighte eathraichean a’ falbh ’s a’ tighinn ma bha oitir iasgaich far an ruigte i.
s.en: The number of Lewis fishermen went in abundance during the eighteenth century so that there was no bay or cove all around the shores in which ships would not be found leaving and coming if there was a fishing bank within reach.

s.gd: Bha taobh an iar an Eilein ainmeil airson bhiorach, agus tha e air innseadh gu robh féill mhór air ola nam biorach anns an dùthaich agus gur iomadh fear is té anns an là ud air na chuir i sult agus dreach.
s.en: The west of the Island was famous for dogfish, and it has been told that there was a large market for dogfish oil in the country and that there was many a man and woman in those days on whom she put fatness and appearance.

s.gd: Bha na Searaich an tòir air truisg is langannan is adagan.
s.en: The Eastsiders were after cod and ling and haddock.

s.gd: Bha an adag airson biadh an teaghlaich, ach bha na truisg agus na langannan air an sailleadh agus air an tiormachadh ris a’ ghréin.
s.en: The haddock was for the family food, but the cod and the ling were salted and dried in the sun.

s.gd: Is iomadh luchd soithich a ghiùlaineadh gu ruige Eireann agus Abhainn Chluaidh fad nam bliadhnachan.
s.en: Many boat people would transport towards Ireland and the River Clyde throughout the years.

s.gd: Gus an ám so cha robh bàtaichean freagarrach aig na h-iasgairean airson druim a’ chuain a thoirt orra.
s.en: Until this time the fishermen dod not have appropriate boats to take on the open sea.

s.gd: B’ e Loch a Ròg an Uige am prìomh àite iasgaich, far an robh sgadan gu leòir air a mharbhadh agus air a shailleadh.
s.en: It was Loch Rog in Uig that was the first fishing place, where there was plenty of herring to kill and to salt.

s.gd: Bha e air a reic bliadhnachan cho saor ri tasdan an crann ris na Suainich a cheannaich a’ chuid bu mhotha dheth aig an ám.
s.en: It was sold for years as cheap as a shilling a cran to the Swedes who bought most of it at the time.

s.gd: Anns na sia bliadhna 1791-1796 chaidh gach bliadhna thairis air a chéile suas ri sia mìle baraille sgadain agus ceithir fichead tonna ’s a h-aon deug de iasg glas a chur á Steòrnabhagh gu Tìr-mór agus gu dùthchannan na Roinn Eorpa.
s.en: In the six years 1791–1796, every year overall up to six thousand barrels of herring and ninety-one tons of grey fish was sent from Stornoway to the Mainland and to European countries.

s.gd: Nuair a chrìon obair na feamann anns na h-eileanan mu thoiseach an ath linne (obair a bha ro fheumail fhads a mhair i), thug sluagh Leódhais aghaidh air a’ mhuir mar nach tug iad riamh roimhe.
s.en: When the seaweed work declined in the islands at the start of the next century (work which was very useful as long as it lasted), the people of Lewis looked to the sea as they never had before.

s.gd: Thog iad bàtaichean na bu mhotha na chleachd iad, agus bha iad a nis comasach air an sgadan a ruighinn far am biodh e.
s.en: They built bigger boats than they had used, and they were now able to reach the herring where it would be.

s.gd: Thàinig soirbheachadh nach bu bheag ri linn sin.
s.en: No little success came at that time.

s.gd: Anns a’ bhliadhna 1870 shailleadh 159,180 baraille sgadain an Steòrnabhagh, a thuilleadh air 297,464 trosg is langa.
s.en: In the year 1870, 159,180 barrels of herring were salted in Stornoway, along with 297,464 cod and ling.

s.gd: O’n ám so gu toiseach an ath linne cha robh fear no té mar a thigeadh gu ìre cosnaidh nach ann air an iasgach a bha e toirt aghaidh, na fir a’ glacadh an éisg agus na caileagan ’g a ghiollachd.
s.en: From that time to the start of the next century, there was no man or woman that would come to the age of earning who would not consider the fishing, the men catching the fish and the girls processing them.

s.gd: Anns na bliadhnachan mu dheireadh de’n naoidheamh linne deug bha ceudan bàta ag iasgach an sgadain a mach á Steòrnabhagh, cuid aca a bhuineadh do na Leódhasaich, ach móran aca as na puirt a Sear le Leódhasaich air bòrd.
s.en: In the last years of the nineteenth century there were hundreds of boats fishing for herring out of Stornoway, some of them which would belong to the Lewismen, but a lot of them out of the Eastern ports with Lewismen on board.

s.gd: Bha seann duine còir, aig an robh ùidh ’san obair, ag innseadh dhomh o chionn ghoirid gun do chunnt e aon fheasgar 970 bàta seòlaidh a’ fàgail na laimrig.
s.en: A kind old man, who was interested in the work, was telling me recently that he had counted one evening 970 sailing boats leaving the harbour.

s.gd: Bu bhòidheach an sealladh iad fo làn aodach eadar a’ Chearc ’s an Tiompan.
s.en: The view was beautiful of them under full sail between the Hen and the Timbrel.

s.gd: Chunnaic mi le mo shùilean iad, cho dlùth air sàil a chéile agus gu saoileadh tu gun coisicheadh fear sgiobalta air bharr nan crann.
s.en: I saw them with my own eyes, as close to each other as a heel and you would have thought that an agile man could walk along the tops of the masts.

s.gd: O’n bhliadhna 1900 bha àireamh nam bàtaichean a sìor dhol na bu lugha gach bliadhna gus an là an diugh.
s.en: From the year 1900, the number of boats was always going smaller every year until today.

s.gd: Chì sinn fhathast an t-aobhar.
s.en: We will still see the cause.

s.gd: B’ e an t-iasgach am prìomh rian cosnaidh aig an t-sluagh fad linntean.
s.en: The fishing was the main mode of employment for the people for centuries.

s.gd: Mur cuireadh an t-iasgach airgead an dorn an iasgair cha bhiodh airgead aige.
s.en: If the fishing had not put money in the fist of the fisherman, he would not have had money.

s.gd: Bha toradh an talamhainn feumail, gun teagamh, ach cha do dh’ fhàs croitear beartach a riamh r’a linn ann an Leódhas.
s.en: The fruits of the soil were useful, without doubt, but no crofter ever became rich in his century in Lewis.

s.gd: Anns a’ bhliadhna 1898 bha 3,930 eadar fhirionnach agus bhalach anns na bàtaichean.
s.en: In the year 1898, there were 3,930 between a man and a boy on the boats.

s.gd: A thuilleadh air sin cha robh nighean eadar sia bliadhna deug agus leth cheud bliadhna nach robh ri giollachd an sgadain fad mìosan an t-samhraidh an Steòrnabhagh, an Sealtain agus anns na puirt a Sear.
s.en: Moreover, there was not a girl between sixteen years old and fifty years old who was not involved in the processing of the herring throughout the summer months in Stornoway, in Shetland and in the Eastern ports.

s.gd: Tha cunntas earbsach againn air gach crann sgadain a mharbhadh a mach a Steornabhagh gach bliadhna o’n bhliadhna 1854 gus an là an diugh.
s.en: We have a reliable account of every cran of herring that was killed out of Stornoway every year from the year 1854 to today.

s.gd: Bha an àireamh sìos agus suas o bhliadhna gu bliadhna.
s.en: The number was down ad up from year to year.

s.gd: Anns a’ bhliadhna 1891 chuireadh 100,000 crann air tìr, ach anns a’ bhliadhna 1894 cha do mharbhadh ach 20,000.
s.en: In the year 1891, 100,000 crans were landed, but in the year 1894 only 20,000 were killed.

s.gd: Reiceadh 152,000 crann sgadain an 1898, ach bliadhnachan an déidh sin bha an àireamh cho beag ri 60,000, agus thuit i aon bhliadhna cho iosal ri 44,000.
s.en: 152,000 crans of herring were sold in 1898, but years after that the numver was as low as 60,000, and it fell one year as low as 44,000.

s.gd: A’ bhliadhna a bhris an cogadh mór a mach, 1914, reiceadh 163,000 crann ach bha an àireamh anns a’ bhliadhna 1921 cho ìosal ri 39,000 crann.
s.en: The year that the great war broke out, 1914, 163,000 crans were sold but the number in the year 1921 was as low as 39,000 crans.

s.gd: Cha do chuireadh barrachd sgadain gu laimrig an Leódhas na rinneadh fad nan sia bliadhnachan 1922-1927.
s.en: More herring were not sent to harbour in Lewis than were done during the six years 1922–1927.

s.gd: O’n bhliadhna 1930 gus na bhris an cogadh mu dheireadh a mach an 1939 ghlacadh thairis air a chéile gach bliadhna mu 56,000 crann.
s.en: From the year 1930 until the last war broke out in 1939, overall around 56,000 crans were caught every year.

s.gd: As déidh na bliadhna 1887, nuair a thòisicheadh air iasgach geamhraidh an toiseach, chuireadh móran sgadain a bharrachd air tìr anns a’ chumantas gach bliadhna na rinneadh roimh an ám sin.
s.en: After the year 1887, when winter fishing was first started, a lot more herring were brought ashore in general every year than before.

s.gd: Chithear o na chaidh a ràdh cheana nach robh gach bliadhna treabhadh dha chéile, ach fhathast gus na bhris a’ cheud chogadh a mach anns a’ bhliadhna 1914 bha muinntir Leódhais a’ dlùth leantuinn iasgach an sgadain, agus cha robh ùidh aca an obair sam bith eile.
s.en: It will be seen from what has been said already that every year ploughing was not ... , but still until the first war broke out in the year 1914, the people of Lewis were closely following the herring fishing, and thy had no interest in any other work.

s.gd: An diugh, an àite nam mìltean a bha an crochadh air iasgach na mara airson am beò-shlàinte chan fhaighear na ficheadan ris an obair.
s.en: Today, in place of the thousands who were involved in sea fishing for their livelihood, you will not find much more than twenty working at it.

s.gd: Dé thachair agus a thug air iasgairean Leódhais an cùl a chur ris a’ mhuir?
s.en: What happened to make the fishermen of Lewis turn their backs on the sea?

s.gd: A thaobh an sgadain, so mar a bha.
s.en: Concerning the herring, this is how it was.

s.gd: Tha Steòrnabhagh fada bho mhargaidhean agus am faradh daor.
s.en: Stornoway is far from markets and freight transport is expensive.

s.gd: Cha b’ urrainn ciùrairean Steòrnabhaigh sgadan ùr a chur gu bailtean an taobh deas, agus air an aobhar sin dh’ fheumte an sgadan a ghiollachd airson gu seasadh e an ùine bha feumail chum a ghiùlain thuca-san a dh’ itheadh e.
s.en: The Stornoway curers were not able to send fresh herring to towns in the south, and for that reason the herring had to be processed so that it would last the time that was needed to transport it to those who would eat it.

s.gd: Bha dà dhòigh air so a dhèanamh—an sgadan a thiormachadh ’s a’ cheothaidh no a shailleadh.
s.en: There were two ways of doing this–drying the herring and smoking or salting it.

s.gd: Chan eil sgadan tiormaichte (kipper) ann as déidheile air a bheil sluagh nam bailtean móra na sgadan samhraidh Steòrnabhaigh, ach tha am faradh gu Tìr-mór a’ togail na prìse, agus gu minic ceannaichear an sgadan saor a roghainn air an sgadan mhath.
s.en: Dried herring (kipper) are not as attractive to the people of the cities as are the Stornoway summer herring, but the freight to the mainland is rising in price, and frequently cheap herring were bought in preference to good herring.

h.gd: Boirionnaich a’ cutadh an sgadain ann an Steòrnabhagh.
h.en: Women gutting the herring in Stornoway.

s.gd: Bha a’ mhór chuid de sgadan samhraidh Steòrnabhaigh air a shailleadh an déidh a chutadh.
s.en: The majority of Stornoway’s summer herring were salted after gutting.

s.gd: Bha so fìor a thaobh an sgadan geamhraidh mar an ceudna.
s.en: This was true regarding the winter herring likewise.

s.gd: B’ e rìoghachdan na Roinn Eòrpa, gu sònraichte a’ Ghearmailt agus an Ruis, a bha ’ga cheannachd.
s.en: It was the kingdoms of Europe, especially Germany and Russia, that were buying it.

s.gd: Nuair a bhris an Cogadh Mór a mach an 1914 chaidh stad a chur air a’ mhalairt so, agus ged a bha a’ Ghearmailt a’ ceannachd an sgadan geamhraidh againne gu a shailleadh iad fhéin fad bhliadhnachan eadar an dà chogadh bha ùine mhór nach robh sgadan idir air a shailleadh an Steòrnabhagh airson dùthchannan eile.
s.en: When the Great War broke out in 1914, a stop was put to this trade, and even though Germany was buying our winter herring to salt them themselves for years between the two wars, there was a long time when herring was not salted at all in Stornoway for other countries.

s.gd: An àite na 153,109 baraille de sgadan saillt a chaidh a reic ann an 1927 cha deach ach 212 baraille a shailleadh ann an 1941, agus cha deach ach 302 a shailleadh ann fad nan trì bliadhna an déidh sin.
s.en: In place of the 153,109 barrels of salted herring that were sold in 1927, only 212 barrels were salted in 1941, and only 302 were salted there during the three years after that.

s.gd: Thòisich a’ Ghearmailt agus an Ruis ag iasgach an sgadain iad fhéin, agus tha an Olaind agus Lochlann a’ cur thuca mar an ceudna.
s.en: Germany and Russia started fishing for herring themselves, and Holland and Scandinavia are sending to them likewise.

s.gd: Ged a rinn Bòrd an Sgadain gach oidhirp airson margadh fhaotainn an taobh a stigh de chrìochan na rìoghachd againn fhéin cha leòir e idir airson iasgairean Albainn agus Shasuinn a chumail air sàl.
s.en: Although the Herring Board made every attemot to find a market inside the borders of our own kingdom itself, it was not enough at all to keep the fishermen of Scotland and England at sea.

s.gd: Tha corr air da fhichead bliadhna nis o thòisich iasgairean Leódhais beag air bheag a’ cur cùil ri iasgach an sgadain, air am mì-mhisneachadh bliadhnachan le goinnead an sgadain mu na puirt iasgaich, agus bliadhnachan eile le lughaid na prìse.
s.en: It is more than forty years now since the Lewis fishermen started little by little turning their backs on the herring fishing, discouraged by years of scarcity of the herring around the fishing ports, and other years with the falling price.

s.gd: Nuair a bhiodh an sgadan pailt anns na lìn bha a’ phris gu bitheanta tuiteam cho ìosal ri crùn an crann, air dhòigh ’s nach robh luach saothrach aig an iasgair as idir.
s.en: When the herring would be abundant in the nets, the price was usually falling as low as a crown the cran, such that there was no labour value for the fishermen at all.

s.gd: Thòisich an òigridh a’ dol do na bailtean a Deas no gu tìrean céine a sholair an teachd-an-tìr.
s.en: The youth started going to the towns of the South or to foreign lands which provided their living.

s.gd: Ach an latha chailleadh margaidhean na Roinn-Eòrpa airson an sgadain shaillt chuir sin cabhag air chabhaig air a’ chùis, gus mu dheireadh gu faodar a ràdh nach fhiach iasgach Steòrnabhaigh a bhith bruidhinn air.
s.en: But the day that markers in Europe were lost for salted herring, that accelerated the matter, until at last it can be said that Stornoway fishing is not worth talking about.

s.gd: An till na Leódhasaich gu iasgach an sgadain tuilleadh?
s.en: Will the Lewismen return to herring fishing again?

s.gd: Chan eil e furasda freagairt earbsach a thoirt do’n cheist sin aig an ám.
s.en: It is not easy to give a reliable answer to the question at the moment.

s.gd: Ach tha e cinnteach gu leòir mur tig leasachadh air cor an iasgaich a dh’ ùine aithghearr bìdh e doirbh òigridh fhaotainn ’s an Eilean a roghnaicheas an obair-sa a bhàrr air obair-tìre.
s.en: But it is certain enough that, unless improvment in the state of fishing comes soon, it will be hard to find youths in the Island who will choose this work in preference to land-work.

s.gd: Tha acfhuinn iasgaich ro chosgail an diugh, agus tha margaidh an sgadain ro neo-chinnteach airson òigridh sgoinneil a thàladh.
s.en: Fishing tackle is very expensive today, and the herring market is very uncertain to attract ambitious youth.

s.gd: Tha cosnadh cinnteach air tìr nas roghnaiche leò na saothair gun duais iomchuidh ’na lorg.
s.en: Reliable employment on land is more preferable for them to labour with no appropriate reward.

s.gd: Nuair nach robh obair eile ann agus a bha pàigheadh glé bhochd air fheabhas, cha robh cor an iasgair a’ coimhead cho doirbh idir, ach an diugh nuair a tha oibrichean eile nas fhasa lorg agus an duais nas cothromaiche agus nas cinntiche chan eil iongnadh ann gu bheil iasgairean na dùthcha cur cùil ris a’ mhuir.
s.en: When there was no other work and when pay was very poor no matter what, the situation of the fisherman was not looking so hard at all, but today when other jobs are easier to find and the rewards are fairer and more certain, there is no surprise that the fishermen of the land are turning their backs on the sea.

s.gd: A rìs, chan fhaigh an t-iasgair cuideachadh ’na fheum o’n riaghaltas mar a gheibh am fear-oibreach air tìr nuair a bhios e mach a obair.
s.en: Again, the fisherman will not get help in need from the government like the working man on land will get, when he is out of work.

s.gd: Chan eil an lagh a’ ceadachadh dha còmhnadh ach ri ám an iasgaich, ma bhios e diomhain, ach chan urrainn e bhith beò air a’ ghaoith aig a’ leithid sin a dh’ ám a bharrachd air ám sam bith eile.
s.en: The law only permits him assistance at the time of fishing, if he is lazy, but he cannot be alive on the wind at that kind of time or at any other time.

s.gd: Mur bi an t-iasgair cinnteach as a theachd-an-tìr fad na bliadhna mar a tha cosnaichean eile cha leig sinn a leas dùil a bhith againn gu lean e an obair daonnan.
s.en: Unless the fisherman is certain of his income all year round like other employees are, we cannot expect that he will always pursue the job.

s.gd: Is e an aon nì a bheir air ais cuid de na chuir cùl ris an iasgach a cheana, agus a dh’ fhadas iarrtas an cridhe na h-òigridh togradh ris an obair, gun dearbhar dhaibh gur fhiach i an t-saothair: gu bheil an duais cinnteach ma nì iad saothair dhligheach.
s.en: The one thing that will bring back some of those who have already turned their backs on the fishing, and which will kindle demand in the hearts of the youth for the work, that it is proved to them that it is worth the efort: that the reward is certain if they do the rightful labour.

s.gd: Ach có as urrainn an dearbhadh sin a thoirt dhaibh mar a tha cùisean an diugh?
s.en: But who can give them that assurance the way things are today?

s.gd: Agus dé dh’ fheumas àite ghabhail mus bi dearbhadh cinnteach ri thoirt seachad?
s.en: And what must take place before there is certain assurance to pass along?

s.gd: Am feum an riaghaltas, iad fhéin, bàtaichean iasgaich agus acfhuinn iasgaich ullachadh, agus iasgairean a phàigheadh air son an oibreachadh?
s.en: Must the government, themselves, provide fishing boats and fishing tackle, and pay fishermen for their work?

s.gd: Mur dèan an riaghaltas e, an dèan buidheannan làidir eile an obair a ghabhail os làimh?
s.en: If the government won’t do it, will other powerful organisations do the work to undertake it?

s.gd: Bìdh feum air sgadan cho fada ’s a bhios daoine ann a dh’ itheas e.
s.en: There will be need for herring as long as there are men who will eat it.

s.gd: Bìdh feum air iasgairean cho fada ’s a dh’ fheumar eòlas na mara gu bhith dìon na rìoghachd.
s.en: There will be need for fishermen as long as we need knowledge of the sea to protect the kingdom.

s.gd: Nach bu chòir a réisd do’n luchd riaghlaidh cnuasachadh gu cùramach mu’n ghnothuch agus gach oidhirp a dhèanamh gu bhith cur an iasgaich-sa air stéidh a ris?
s.en: Shouldn’t the governors reflect carefully again on the matter and make every effort to put this fishing on a solid basis again?

s.gd: An uair a tha an rìoghachd againne cho mór an urra ri dùthchannan céine air son na dh’fheumar chum an sluagh a bheathachadh nach eil e ro iomchuidh, chan e a mhàin gun giùlaineadh an talamh de bhàrr nas urrainn e chur dheth, ach mar an ceudna, gun dèante gach dìcheall gu bhith glacadh an éisg a tha am freasdal caomh a’ stiùireadh dh’ ionnsaigh nan cladaichean againn?
s.en: When our own kingdom is so largely dependent on foreign countries for that which is needed to support the population, is it not too appropriate, not only that the land would carry ..., but likewise, that every effort would be made to catch the fish that providence is leading towards our own shores?
